body: @rmuir We are using the [debug package](https://www.npmjs.com/package/debug) that suggests `DEBUG_COLORS=false` environment variable. Let me know whether that helps.

@dgozman thank you for responding. I set `DEBUG_COLORS`, and it seems not to respect it: e.g. `pw:api` log messages are some still in cyan color and `pw:browser` is very dark.

```
 # enable playwright debugging logs
 ENV DEBUG=pw:api,pw:browser
+# disable debugger colors
+ENV DEBUG_COLORS=false
```

I did find a partial workaround looking more into the sources: for the `junit` reporter if I set `stripANSIControlSequences: true` then it strips all ansi including debug output, which solves my problem for one of the reporters.

unfortunately the `line` reporter doesn't seem to have such an option: any ideas on other things I could try?

I don't know typescript at all really, I'm just a CI/CD guy who deals with testing stuff across many programming languages. Would there be any appetite for respecting `NO_COLOR` environment variable as described in https://no-color.org/ ? It works with popular packages such as `npm` and `python` and really helps save time in these situations: I have looked thru plenty of typescript sources today and searched for things like `process.env` across whole codebase trying to figure out how to solve this.

Just as a guess, i think high-level the issue making it impossible to disable colors with these env vars, might be that they seem to get overridden by some sources to "force color":
https://github.com/microsoft/playwright/blob/356517cddbd8f71946065da19b3f7a64b5d0c4df/packages/playwright/src/plugins/webServerPlugin.ts#L42-L43

(maybe this code is not relevant, I'm not sure what I'm looking at)

npm `debug` package docs lead me to https://www.npmjs.com/package/supports-color which says:
> The use of FORCE_COLOR overrides all other color support checks.

Unrelated to this behaviour around colours. You are using this environment variable to debug test flakes. The environment variable is not intended to be used for that / doesn't give you the best user experience. Have you considered [Trace Viewer](https://playwright.dev/docs/trace-viewer-intro) in order to debug your failing tests?

> Unrelated to this behaviour around colours. You are using this environment variable to debug test flakes. The environment variable is not intended to be used for that / doesn't give you the best user experience. Have you considered [Trace Viewer](https://playwright.dev/docs/trace-viewer-intro) in order to debug your failing tests?

@mxschmitt Of course I archive the trace.zip in jenkins when test fails as it is definitely useful! But the playwright debug output is extremely useful in the logs for different reasons:
1. failure triage (versus debugging). if test fails i go to "failed tests" in jenkins and it shows stderr with `pw:api` calls with associated timing information. it gives "basic test logging" with output consistent with any other test in any other tool/programming language (and we have many others in the build): textual output from the build is helpful for at least a basic understanding of which test failed and why, without downloading zip files and running a GUI.
2. debugging low-level failures. in our tests we do some tricky things such as kerberos single-sign-on, we have encountered bugs in chromium, we have workaround place for said bugs, and special setup in place, hence having access to `pw:browser` logs is important.

In case anyone else struggles with disabling color like this, I did figure out a very-ugly workaround for the line reporter using `sed` to scrub out the colors:
```
set -exo pipefail; ...
docker-compose exec browser-tests xvfb-run -s '-screen 0 1920x1080x24' npx playwright test | sed 's/\x1B\[[0-9;]\{1,\}[A-Za-z]//g'
```

combined with the `stripANSIControlSequences: true` in the junit reporter, both reporters now work in jenkins without having to 'decrypt' the ANSI escapes.

issue.title: fix(test runner): cleanup DEBUG_COLORS usage

repository.name: playwright
repository.description: Playwright is a framework for Web Testing and Automation. It allows testing Chromium, Firefox and WebKit with a single API.

issue.body:
`DEBUG_COLORS` we default to `1`, but we should not do that when it is already defined to some value supplied by the user.

Closes #32543.

body: Thank you @dgozman ! With playwright 1.48, I just set `DEBUG_COLORS=false` in environment and removed all hacks and it works.

issue.title: [Feature]: support stripANSIControlSequences in json reporter

repository.name: playwright
repository.description: Playwright is a framework for Web Testing and Automation. It allows testing Chromium, Firefox and WebKit with a single API.

issue.body:
### Version

1.48.2

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create simple test:
  ```typescript
import { test, expect } from '@playwright/test';

test('color', () => {
  expect('foo').toBe('bar');
})
```
2. Run Playwright with colors turned off: `FORCE_COLOR=0 DEBUG_COLORS=false npx playwright test`

### Expected behavior

I expect the output to lack any colors.

### Actual behavior

Playwright's own output has no colors, but the output from `expect` does have colors. This part:

    Error: expect(received).toBe(expected) // Object.is equality

    Expected: "bar"
    Received: "foo"

### Additional context

This seems related to #32543.

https://github.com/microsoft/playwright/pull/32764 changed `DEBUG_COLORS` to respect the environment, here (on line 40): https://github.com/microsoft/playwright/blob/ecf6f27159de43cc12964e190e5241b4382abff5/packages/playwright/src/runner/workerHost.ts#L39-L40

If I make the same adjustment to `FORCE_COLOR` on line 39, the colors from `expect` disappear too.

### Environment

```shell
System:
    OS: Linux 5.15 Ubuntu 22.04.5 LTS 22.04.5 LTS (Jammy Jellyfish)
    CPU: (8) x64 Intel(R) Core(TM) i5-10310U CPU @ 1.70GHz
    Memory: 1.29 GB / 11.69 GB
    Container: Yes
  Languages:
    Bash: 5.1.16 - /usr/bin/bash
  npmPackages:
    @playwright/test: ^1.48.2 => 1.48.2
```
